- The article deals with a contingent and very relevant problem, and includes both a national diagnosis of the use of good practices and a solution (concrete good practices). - The language is appropriate. - The article feels like the concatenation of three different articles: (1) results of a survey, (2) good security practices, (3) incorporation of good practices. - The order of the sections would be better if it reflected this order (revised version is #2, #1, #3). - The article has no validation of any kind, not even by expert evaluation.

The article presents practical recommendations for the development of secure software. Recommended best practices for developing software that is proactive against attacks are described, and a cost analysis of these practices in software development is performed. All based on a review of practices proposed in the literature and its contrast with data obtained from a survey in companies. Finally a guide is recommended. It would be ideal to apply the proposed guide to companies not involved in the survey that served to originate it, so that its effectiveness can be independently evaluated.

The topic is very interesting and a guide to incorporate security practices can be very helpful. - The presentation (description, stage and use) of the 9 practices for the development of secure software. - The “real state of software development in Chile” (as indicated in his paper) cannot be achieved with only 22 surveys out of a total of 50. - Presents nine tables that correspond to the practices for the development of secure software, but the guide presents 10 practices. explain why? - I suggest improving the guide, the greatest contribution is in the incorporation sequence that it proposes. Also, it should not explain the practice in Remarks or differentiate it from other practices in that column, but should give suggestions on how to apply it. - In the text it indicates "Later on, three extra practices will also be presented..." What are they or did I not read correctly? - According to format, put at least 5 keywords. - I suggest mentioning the practices before showing each table. - Some references are incomplete, for example, missing year in reference 17, missing year and type of event in reference 11, missing editorial in reference 19 (is it a book?) - Some titles have a comma inside the quotes, example, reference 1

An experience of using ICT for academic collaboration is explained in an orderly and didactic way. The originality of the work is not its strong dimension, see long-standing works such as Gorton et al. (1997) and current as Lanunile et al. (2010). However, the relevance of the topic as a reference pattern in activities related to scientific theses, associated with its good presentation, make it a contribution. It is suggested, with a view to publication in a journal, that the efficiency and effectiveness of the activities be compared without the support of these tools versus the current reality (with tools). Examples of possible questions to answer from this exploratory analysis: What are the main activities where the use of collaborative tools is key? What changes in the design of these tools should be developed in the future? Are there student/academic profiles more conducive to the adoption of these platforms? References: Gorton, I., Hawryszkiewycz, I., and Ragoonaden, K. 1997. Collaborative tools and processes to support software engineering shift work. BT Technology Journal 15, 3 (Jul. 1997), 189-198. Filippo Lanubile, Christof Ebert, Rafael Prikladnicki, Aurora Vizcaíno, "Collaboration Tools for Global Software Engineering," IEEE Software, vol. 27, no. 2, p. 52-55, Mar./Apr. 2010.

The authors describe a methodology for collaboratively developing theses and reports using technologies commonly used in software development. They also describe specific tools and their benefits, such as Latex and Git. Finally, they propose a workflow for the development of projects of this nature. The main value of the article lies in the application of knowledge that students already master - that is, software development techniques and tools - to a different problem, such as the case of theses and reports. All this, with the aim of making the process more efficient. 1.- The emphasis of the article is the solution without making a detailed analysis of the problem that is intended to be solved. In other words, there are no answers to the following questions: a.- what exactly is the problem? b.- What impacts does this problem generate? c.- Why is it important to solve the problem? d.- What solutions have been implemented to date? e.- What advantages does the proposed solution have with respect to the previous ones? 2.- In my opinion, the article should emphasize more the methodology and workflow. For example, adding a diagram -using a visual language- that allows, on the one hand, to understand the general thesis development process and, on the other, to distinguish the roles, activities and associated technologies in each phase of the report. 3.- Some aspects of the language and the rigor of certain statements must be taken care of, such as: "(given the rather atrocious spelling enjoyed by engineers)". Do the authors have any empirical support to support this claim? Is it necessary to resort to such prosaic language to justify the convenience of using a certain technological tool? By the way, I recommend reviewing the expressions: "it is not public" (point 3.1) and "Having access directly..." (point 3.2)

This paper involves the development of an application that simulates the BB84 protocol, an orderly work is appreciated and without a doubt the understanding of some concepts of quantum physics that support quantum cryptography such as the non-cloning theorem and the principle of superposition and Interleaving is a task that has its merits, in addition, the use of software engineering in the construction of the application is appreciated, which is a very positive aspect, since generally when software creation is involved in frontier knowledge areas, resort to code-and-fix, with all the disadvantages that this entails. I believe that this manuscript should be directed to the area of cryptography and security, in my specialty, which is computing in distributed environments, I do not see significant relevance and contribution of the manuscript, using RMI in my opinion is not a contribution per se, because RMI is easy to use if JAVA is handled, however, it is not interoperable since it does not support other programming languages, in addition, systems based on RMI as they grow have a performance problem, the more they grow the slower they become, on the other hand , according to some purists a client/server system is not a distributed system, according to others the client/server case is the most basic case of distributed computing, in short, speaking strictly from the area of distributed computing I do not see relevance in this area of this manuscript, however, it seems to me that in another area the paper could be pertinent, since it is an orderly, clear and well-written work. I am not an expert in the area of cryptography, but a few years ago I once heard an Englishman talk about quantum cryptography in a seminar and he mentioned a large number of simulators and applications, he even said that he had applications that already used quantum cryptography among several kilometers through fiber optics, so I think it is best to evaluate this manuscript in that area and not in the area of grid/distributed systems, because in this area the paper, in my opinion, does not have original aspects, since it uses trivial aspects of client/server principles. As I have said before, the paper has more issues of quantum physics and cryptography than distributed computing, for which abstracting myself from the area that concerns me, I see the use of a distributed environment technology used as a client/server, not interoperable and with scalability restrictions. A positive aspect in the paper is that the use of software engineering is appreciated. Regarding the area of grid computing and distributed systems, the manuscript does not contain relevant aspects, it uses RMI to implement a client/server system, however, RMI is easy to use and as a well-known paradigm in computing, performance is opposed to ease of use, RMI does not escape that, because it is easy to use, but it does not have scalability. The document is well presented, perhaps table 2 and table 3 would be better merged using rows as computer and in the columns the details of the ne2rk, especially if there is more than a client/server scheme, for example, a ne2rk distribution ring. quantum keys, with more than 2 computers involved. I think being introduced to the crypto and security area would be more pertinent.

Innovative proposal for the application of an industrial engineering methodology to the field of requirements engineering. - There is no unification of terms throughout the document, related to the requirements engineering phase: 'eduction', 'elicitation'... The same term must always be used. - There is no evidence of how the gradual 'improvements' of the elicitation process are quantified, and the 'improvement' in the quality of the documentation. How do you measure that improvement? - There are writing and spelling errors, particularly in the use of accents (tildes) and punctuation marks (use of commas and semicolons). The article proposes the use of a work philosophy from another area of engineering, to improve the quality levels of the requirements documents generated in a requirements elicitation process. I consider that from the technical point of view it would be important that they support the analysis of the results that they propose in a quantified measurement or comparison, which allows, through a more formal method than the descriptive one, to generate the conclusions of 'improvement' in the quality of the products. associated with the requirements engineering process. There is no evidence of how they reach the conclusions generated, what are they based on to say that it is better or not, that it has fewer errors or not? It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering processes. Currently it contributes to reduce the crisis associated with this phase of development of software products. The organization of the document can be improved considerably. I consider that a large part of the article is dedicated to expressing the associated conceptual framework, and less to the application of the technique in the case study and the analysis of results, sections in which the proposal presented can be supported more. Likewise, there are spelling and writing errors that, if avoided, can give greater value to the presentation of the article.

Try to apply a new strategy to requirements management. The applicability of manufacturing process techniques to software processes is not supported or considered. Although it is true that there are authors such as Demming who state that it is possible to do so, there are other authors such as Sommerville who state that due to the characteristics of software development, manufacturing process techniques are not applicable to software. The authors of this article provide no support regarding the validity of this aspect. The article begins stating that the proposal is to improve the elicitation of requirements, however, then it is derived that what is improved is the generation of the SRS. The elicitation and generation of the requirements document are different aspects. In the case of experimentation that is presented, it is not seen anywhere that problems are solved neither in the reduction nor in the generation of the SRS, they are rather implementation problems. The errors detected are basic aspects that any programmer with a minimum of experience knows how to solve, without the need for the SRS to specify the type of minimum validations that must be carried out as part of the system tests. The proposal lacks practical guidelines to help in its application. How should these POKA-YOKE reviews be carried out? What aspects should you pay attention to? Are there artifacts to guide the review? There are editing errors in the text (repeated words) There are spelling problems (word stress)

The paper describes an experience concerning the automated inspection of spectra for the Pipeline Hubble Legacy Archive Grism data.  Comments:  In the conclusions the authors say that "We have identified 2 classes of flawed spectra which were not picked up by the automatic classification because of their very small number of training samples. Per construction machine learning techniques can not classify such outliers." This sentence should be further explained. As Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman say in The Elements of Statistical Learning (see Chapter 7): "it is too difficult to give a general rule on how much training data is enough; among other things, this depends on the signal-to-noise ratio of the underlying function, and the complexity of the models being fit to the data. " So, by just saying that the number of training samples is small you do not provide enough information to decide whether machine learning techniques are adequate or not to solve a problem.  Other minor comments:  + If reference [2] has not yet been written or published it should be deleted from the paper.  The dataset may be of scientific importance.  It is mainly descriptive.

This manuscript addresses an interesting solution based in machine learning techniques to classify spectra legacy data of the Hubble Space Telescope in order to publish the results and "good" spectra in Internet to scientific community. The manuscript is well-written and results are robust. Experiment is sound and the manuscript seems acceptable in the current form. The work can be short, but very interesting to the Infonor and JCC community.  The main problem of the paper is that it is difficult to compare results for the classifiers utilized. A confusion matrix and parameters for each classifier could clarify results.

Interesting application domain.  Nothing new from a machine learning perspective. They authors should provide more information about the models they have obtained with the different classifiers (feature subset selection used, selected features, accuracies, statistical significance on the differences on accuracies, the models themselves, ...). Semi-supervised classification is the appropriate method for the last paragraph in the "Methodology" section.

This paper presents a tool (SAVE) for software architecture verification. SAVE performs a static check of rules associated with permitted and prohibited dependencies between elements of the design and the code, and allows a report to be delivered on the consistency between both levels with respect to said rules. In general, the tool seems quite powerful for 2 reasons: the use of simple rules and the inclusion of pre-defined rule sets for widely used design patterns. This, in my opinion, is the most important difference with other similar frameworks. The writing is, in some places, not very objective. In particular, I would suggest avoiding excessive use of adjectives for which no supporting evidence is provided. For example, in several places I noticed the use of "powerful tool", "intuitive tool" or similar (not only referring to SAVE, but to other works). In all these cases, no evidence is explicitly provided to support the use of such adjectives. Another detail that requires fixing is the title that appears in the PDF file: "Prediction of behavioral dynamics...", which does not match the title of the paper. The authors probably used a template from a previous paper with that title.

The verification of the architecture of a software product can be a great contribution to its quality, therefore, any tool that facilitates this task is a contribution to software engineering. They present evidence of a previous review of alternative or complementary methods and tools to the proposal. The descriptions presented are accompanied by explanatory examples. The role and interaction of the domain expert is not clear. In the initial sections it says that the tool performs static and dynamic analysis, however at the end of the article, in the identification of possible improvements of SAVE, it is proposed to include dynamic analysis, which contradicts the initial statement. The description of how the tool works is not clear enough. The quality of the figures is not adequate, due to their size and resolution it is not possible to appreciate the details well. Article writing can be improved. There are several sentences where connectors are missing, for example "In this section, we will see SAVE manages to recover existing dependencies in the source code...." Many errors in the accentuation of words.

consider, first of all, that the field of development of the subject (software development in research environments...) does not "grant permission" to carry out this development in a more informal way (times, loose versions, little documentation, etc. .). 2nd, I don't see why only SCRUM is proposed, without making basic comparisons with the other "classic" exponents of agile methodologies (XP and FDD), which gives a certain "lightness" to the initial analysis by the authors (no doubt could go a little deeper, especially with XP).

This paper performs a categorization of ways to integrate business rules in a design using the aspect-oriented paradigm and proposes a documentation template for business rules based on this categorization. The paper provides useful information about the particular problem, as well as a reasonable categorization of different aspects of this problem. It is a good starting point for an investigation in that line. Although the information provided in the paper is highly relevant for research on this topic, it is insufficient to accept it as a complete and self-contained work. The reason is that the paper focuses on identifying problems and proposing an artifact (the template) that should solve those problems. However, it does not present evidence as to why this template is a good alternative to solve these problems. For this, the elements mentioned in the future work are required, specifically the formal specification and the automatic tool to create templates and map them to AOP. My suggestion is to wait until these elements are ready to complete this paper and send it to a new conference.

The work presents a viable alternative to solve the problem of changing business rules. It can be improved by adding a little more background to the aspect topic, since prior knowledge of this topic is assumed, so the paper is not self-contained.

The paper presents a methodology to address the complexity of implementing business rules without making changes to the base functionality of a system. It proposes a clear methodology based on documentation through templates to manage and analyze the impact of carrying out the implementation of a business rule via aspect orientation. The reasons presented to indicate that the OA approach to encapsulate the connection between the business rules and the base functionality is not a trivial task, they are general and should be addressed in more depth. It does not present formal evidence that the use of the proposed templates specifically solves a problem. It is suggested to present a solved problem through the tool that is under development that automatically handles the templates. Failing this, demonstrate the application to a specific problem.

The development of a prototype for an automatic software requirements allocation tool among developers is presented. This tool can be very useful for software development teams. It is about making a contribution through this tool to the quality of the products developed. The heuristics used for assigning requirements to programmers are not explained. A study of the existing requirements management tools is not presented, where it is shown that there are no alternative tools to the one presented. And if there are alternatives, justify why develop a new one. The functionalities of the tool are not clearly explained. There is no evidence of the improvement of the process by including this tool, it is only said in the conclusions that "the change in the quality of the process is perceptible" The bibliographic references used are mostly web pages, a bibliographic review in databases is not noted. specialized data. The figures are not well distinguished. The bibliographical references do not comply with the established format. You must write in the third person.

Innovative proposal for requirements planning for a software factory, as a contribution towards improving the quality of projects. - Although the title of the article is oriented towards 'requirements planning', this point is only addressed again when they narrate how they implemented the prototype. - They do not include a conceptual base that allows sustaining the role that requirements management plays in the software development process and particularly in the quality assurance of the process. - It is not evident how with a contribution in the automatic planning of the requirements for the software factory, this will allow you to reduce your development times (estimated vs. real) and therefore ensure higher quality. - The relationship that exists between the proposal made within the CMMI framework is not very clear. The article proposes a requirements planning model, supported by an automatic tool. The prototype they propose is interesting and relevant. I think that the model and method that they propose associated with it, which is actually the real contribution of the authors, can be better organized. I consider that from the technical point of view it would be important that the analysis of the results that they propose with the case study of the bank, be done through an interpretation or quantitative comparison, which really shows that with this automatic planning the quality is really being improved. of the process and/or at least the estimation and actual execution of development times will be shorter, a scenario that, according to background information, has already been justified in its direct relationship with quality. It is an interesting proposal that can be applied in real cases of requirements engineering management processes. Currently, it would contribute to the reduction of time associated with this phase of software product development, and consequently with the quality of the process. Bearing in mind that Requirements Engineering has so many causes and problematic actions, which generate software crises and therefore an affectation in quality management, it remains an open question whether a contribution towards the 'planning' of the requirement really achieves a considerable effect, with respect to other causes or crucial points such as 'prioritization of requirements', validation and/or its traceability as such. The organization of the document can be improved in the following aspects: - Some of the figures that are included are not necessary, since they really do not provide anything additional to what is described in the text, and visually they do not say much. - In the 'APARD Design' section they mention many technical aspects characteristic of reference software factories, which do not give more weight to the intention of the article, nor are they giving really influential data for the application. - The quality of the figures can be optimized (mainly those that show the internal components of the algorithm and the actions of use of the system -profiles, since they are the ones that show the greatest contribution). - There are several drafting errors that should be reviewed (for example: the use of 'on the basis of' should be changed to 'based on'; 'is used', to 'is used'.. )

The APARD tool - The topic associated with requirements and software factory is interesting - The practical case that considers the use of APARD with its advantages and limitations is not detailed - The section that explains the implementation of the APARD solution should be improved - Improve conclusions - The presentation: with spelling and writing errors, written in the first person, figures with very small letters, white letters in figures make it difficult to read, references written in different ways, etc. - It is recommended not to use Wikipedia as a reference for a scientific article. - Author is missing in references 6, subject name is missing in reference 13 - Reference 7 is written with author differently from the others and with title before author. - Change “Keywords” to “Keywords”. - According to format, put at least 5 keywords. - It makes reference in another format, for example, Greenfield and Short(2003) - There is a lot of detail of technologies and tools and products detailed in the Technological Specification section of APARD - What does IQNET[z] mean? - I suggest putting the sections that make up the paper in the Introduction.

The subject of the article is new and necessary in the process modeling literature. The work in general presents a poor theoretical development. To carry out the comparison between the process modeling techniques, a methodology must be built that effectively shows the advantages of one method over the other. The comparison made between the methods must be presented for a general case, since nowhere does the methodology explain what is going to be applied to a particular situation. The methodology of the article does not adequately explain the way in which the comparison was developed, it only exposes the decision criteria used in its construction, which does not allow an adequate evaluation of the results obtained. The research question and the objectives of the study carried out are not clearly stated.

This paper presents important problems in its formulation. Practical experience papers must deliver more than a simple description of the developed system: they must clearly indicate what new knowledge, technique or solution was obtained from said experience. Consequently, a paper of this nature should include, at least, the following essential elements: - An introduction that clearly explains the purpose of the work: (a) the problem that was solved directly or indirectly with the practical experience, (b) why the problem is important and not trivial and (c) why this experience provided new information within that context (not obtained with similar experiences). - Theoretical framework - The description of the system: it should not be a mere enumeration of its components and functionalities, but clearly indicate those elements that, during its development, provided relevant information to the study problem. - Conclusions: they must be aligned with the elements of the introduction and must be supported by the evidence provided in the description of the system. Analyzing the paper from this perspective, we find important problems: First, the introduction is not clear regarding the purpose of the work and. The only part where the objectives are mentioned is in the 5th paragraph, where it is indicated that the case study is "to empirically demonstrate the development costs" associated with the technologies shown in the paper. This, along with "highlighting the main features and potential strengths of CakePHP and MVC.." seem to be the core elements of the paper. Second, the system description is not very different from a system manual; essential evidence is missing to support the elements of the introduction: associated development costs (time, people, resources) that are supposed to be lower than with another methodology. Although the sections describing CakePHP and MVC have information relevant to the problem, they do not add value to the work if they are not supported by evidence obtained directly from development experience with this technology. Above all, I missed a comparison with some other similar experience, clearly indicating what improvements CakePHP/MVC introduces to development. Finally, the conclusions of the paper are not aligned with the elements indicated in the introduction; some of them deliver information out of context (findings #5 and #6) or are irrelevant (finding #2); others lack supporting evidence (conclusion #1) or are not explicit in associating the evidence with the conclusion (conclusions #3 and #4). Apart from the previous observations, the paper also requires improvements in the presentation of the information. For example, the value that the SQL code in figures 10 and 11 deliver to the paper is not explicit. Figures 12-15 are not adequately described. A person who does not understand command line work well may end up totally disoriented and will not understand the arguments put forward. For all these reasons, the paper is not in a position to be accepted for publication.

column11: The article presents a study of the perception that requirements engineers (novices and experts) have in relation to the effectiveness of the different elicitation techniques for the discovery of requirements in a software development project. The article deals with a topic that deserves some attention given the large number of elicitation techniques that exist and the disorientation of requirements engineers regarding which one to use in a given context. The study carried out considers as novice Engineers who do not have knowledge of education techniques and one of the attributes that must be qualified as the basis of the comparative study, is precisely their experience. In fact, as a conclusion, it is stated that "a broader training and mainly of a practical type, is necessary so that novice engineers can decide ....", that is a Perogrullo. A greater range of context attributes should be considered, such as those suggested in [14], which allow more truthful conclusions.

It is a study carried out under a formal methodology (grid technique). The objective behind the study is to improve the preparation of strategies for training in requirements elicitation techniques, which is a contribution given the relevance of Requirements Engineering in software development. The study covers a wide variety of education techniques, including the most used in practice. The study was applied to people who belong to a single institution (Polytechnic University of Madrid), without a doubt this is a limitation since they all have exactly the same training, it would be interesting to apply the study to new engineers with different training. The conclusions obtained from the study are not new, they confirm what could logically be expected.

The article performs a performance comparison for GPU and CPU-based implementations for the same algorithm. GPU programming is a very current topic in HPC. There are problems in the presentation of the article and the images are not well contextualized. Implementations and performance comparisons between GPU and CPU are a topic already addressed in existing works. The article relatively specifically describes the implementation and its details, along with the problems encountered. GPU programming is a very current topic in high-performance computing and its comparison with CPU-based programming seems relevant to me. It would be advisable to improve the order of the article, better relating the images and tables. There are obvious misspellings within the content of the work.

The manuscript involves the use of GPU, a technology that for a couple of years has had more and more to say in the area of HPC. The document has relatively good structure, comparisons are made and there are some interesting graphics. The document has some shortcomings that make it confusing, for example, page 7 is a complete mess, Figure 7 is not well explained, the tables are treated as figures, there is a difference between what an image and a graph represent, so which must be treated independently. There is a text that explains Figure 6, which by the way is a table, that text is not part of the body of the paper, is it? It is very difficult to read that page. I am not an expert in the SIFT algorithm, so when I read the paper it is not clear to me if they used the SiftGPU code created by Changchang Wu or took it as a base and applied some modifications to it. On the other hand, it would have been interesting to know why the implementation in CUDA, the implementation in multicore and the serial could give different results, if after all the three approaches are the SIFT algorithm. I have been programming parallel applications for more than 12 years and for the same algorithm I have never observed different results, if after all the algorithm is the same, now, when variants are introduced to the original algorithm in order to force parallelism, have different results, but it is no longer the original algorithm. Reading other papers on the subject, I do not find so much originality, the document does not help much to draw conclusions either. The paper has data from runs and compares different approaches, but I still have a big question as to why the same algorithm with a sequential approach and a parallel one with GPU can yield different results. GPU is an issue that has its thanks, especially for the money savings that its use implies in the long term, so it could be good to spread this work to spread this technology. The document is messy, it is necessary to differentiate what is a figure, a graph and a table, in addition page 7 is very difficult to read and the explanation of the data tables is confused with the body of the paper.

The article generally proposes an architecture based on the Windows Azure platform to develop applications for Cloud Computing, which is a very current paradigm in computing technologies. Some pointers or comparisons of why using Windows Azure and not other platforms for cloud computing applications would be appreciated. The use of Windows Azure for the development of an application for Cloud Computing does not seem very original to me and the proposed architecture is based on MVC, which is widely used in the area of application development. The article describes in a very general way the concepts of Cloud Computing, MVC, Web Services and REST. The topic of Cloud Computing is a current computing paradigm, and from that point of view, the article is relevant. It would be appreciated to define the acronyms at least once, define whether to speak of "the cloud" or "the cloud", references in the "Proposed Architecture" section and some figures showing the proposed architecture.

Description of the components of the Windows Azure cloud computing platform. - Brief description of the concept of cloud computing. - There is a lack of discussion regarding the possible disadvantages or adverse scenarios of a "cloud implementation" - The summary speaks of "...detailing the experience in building a platform to build public and open clouds", but it is only limited to the description of the Azure platform. - Very little depth in the description of the application that was mounted on the cloud platform. Given the title and abstract, more analysis is expected in terms of the advantages and disadvantages of developing using this platform. - Writing problems within the same work. - Certain sections seem more like a commercial "brochure" than an academic work.

The paper has a relatively coherent structure, it introduces a series of concepts that could be useful for someone who does not know the subject, it talks about architectural patterns and describes windows azure For someone who knows the subject it is tedious to read already known definitions, on the other hand, the The title of the paper is not consistent with what is written in the manuscript, in fact at times it gave me the feeling of reading a commercial brochure more than a scientific work, cloud computing and especially its implementations, such as windows azure, have advantages and disadvantages , to mention some disadvantages: loss of control, performance, privacy, in Latin America all countries have serious bandwidth problems, for which cloud computing can be a risk rather than a benefit if it does not improve a basic aspect, improve data ne2rks. I think the case study should have been explained more, since it is the essence that shows whether cloud computing is useful or just another buzzword that the commercial area of IT companies wants to sell us. The paper is mainly limited to explaining concepts and benefits rather than showing the benefits and qualities through an example or practical case. The case study is not detailed and the development of applications is not seen from a critical point of view, only positive aspects are mentioned and not the negative ones. Although cloud is a current term, after participating in several conferences on grid computing and collaborative systems, I am still not sure if cloud is a buzzword in the commercial area or if it really has something new that the concepts that were coined before did not have, although I do not know a critical and objective view of the subject, in parts it looks like a commercial brochure, I believe that an open discussion of the subject can be generated to help answer the doubts that exist around the term cloud computing. The paper has writing errors in the abstract, however, it has coherence and an evolution of the theme, although the theme in which it evolves is not aligned with the title of the document.

The paper introduces a segmentation procedure for breast tissue images using SVM.  General comments:  a) Concerning the proposed approach: The segmentation method introduced only considers local color/gray value information. Perhaps introducing other features related to the membrane's local (e.g. the membrane has symmetry properties that can be exploited) or global (e.g. continuity, approximately circular shape) properties may improve the segmentation results.  Feature selection is also a key component to improve performance. Use a feature selection procedure.  b) Concerning the experimentation: You should describe the experiments with sufficient detail so others can replicate them: a) Make your data publicly available b) Explain how you have selected the classifier's parameters (parameter selection in an SVM is critical and may improve notably the performance).  You should join Figs 10 and 9 in a single plot so we can better see the differences.  You only provide qualitative segmentation results (Figs. 12, 14, 15), but quantitative results are also very important. Specially when it comes to comparisons. You should quantitatively compare your algorithm with other competing works in the literature.  c) Concerning paper organization: The paper is well written and clearly introduces the problem, describes the relevant literature and presents the solution. I have a few comments concerning the paper organization: a) Problem statement and literature review (intro and theoretical framework sections) are in my opinion a bit long, compared to other important sections, e.g. feature extraction and experimentation which are just one paragraph each. b) Although English is in general correct, there are some small mistakes that could be solved by having it read by a professional. c) There are 2 "proposed method" sections  Well written paper. Good literature review.  It only shows very preliminary results.

This work shows a segmentation approach of breast tissue images for the binary classification of pixels of an image by means of SVM, to determine the presence or absence of the staining of the membranes of cancer cells. This work is interesting and valuable, due to the difficulty of obtaining this type of images and the interdisciplinary approach, also presenting an interesting future work. It is well written and the results shown, although partial, seem correct and justified. Check the wording and typography of page 4 in its first and penultimate paragraphs. The main weakness of this work may be the low number of test images and the lack of comparison with other methods. It would also be desirable to show general results of the classification and not only of the validation process. Furthermore, the properties explained in the scoring table (completeness and intensity) are not used directly in the classification process.

The paper presents a medical test based on images of tissue sections. The approach proposed to cancer cells segmentation (membrane localisation) is based on local pixel features and SVM classification.  The paper describes quite well the practical problem it deals with (cancer cells segmentation on images) and it is generally well written.  - The paper approach described in the paper seems a first try on the problem and follows others in a quite similar (but new) problem. Moreover, the paper concludes that the proposed approach is not good enough.  - The features used for classification lacks of frequency information around each pixel (although it used the first derivative with sobel). Most texture descriptors in the literature use frequency information from gabor wavelets, fourier coefficients, DCT, etc. Why not use this kind of information? Why you have chosen this 7 features and not other ones? The paper lacks of experimental evaluation on different features sets.

The presented article describes how to model a multi-agent system according to the "GAIA" agent-oriented methodology to model the traceability of requirements. GAIA's proposal to model the traceability of requirements through multi-agent systems seems to be novel. The presentation of the article is quite confusing, the document has some spelling, writing and structuring errors, references are made to tables that are figures, unreferenced tables are presented, figure 6 does not exist, the item "results" must be changed or described elsewhere in the document. insufficient conclusions.

The article describes several approaches to develop requirements, and applies one of them (GAIA) to the construction of multi-agent systems (MAS). - The Introduction is very long and covers many topics; it should be divided into several sections, leaving only the general context and description of the rest of the article in the Introduction. - There is no example to illustrate the technique, which is described in 1.5 pages, being the essence of the contribution. - There is no validation of any kind.

The use of the GAIA methodology is proposed for traceability to the requirements, the proposed approach is based on the social capacity of the agents to process knowledge, perceive changes in the environment and communication. It is a complex task, because in software development a great variety of models and diagrams are used that facilitate the representation of knowledge, these artifacts are modified over time. These changes come mainly from the user. It is required to deepen the practical application of the proposal to better evaluate the scientific and practical contribution.

The article presents an eye detection and monitoring system to help psychological clinical analysis. General comments. Much has been published on the subject of the article. However, no other directly related relevant works are cited to help us locate the proposal within the literature. A good starting point can be the special issue of the journal: Computer Vision and Image Understanding Volume 98 , Issue 1 (April 2005) Special issue on eye detection and tracking The experimental part of the work is very short. It is important to describe in detail the data used in the experimentation, what the capture conditions are, and even make them public so that other researchers can compare them. As for the results, it is not enough to give a percentage of successes. False positives and negatives must be analyzed and related to the technique used and, if possible, to future research topics. Other comments: The article mentions that response speed has been considered, but no figures are provided. In the introduction reference [3] is cited in the related review on the psychological aspects of the article, when this reference seems to be of mathematical morphology. Some references are incomplete: + In 1 and 2 the editorial is missing + In 3 the conference/magazine. + In page 5 the volume, number and pages The article deals with a subject of great technical and practical interest. A system is described that appears not to be fully developed.

The work presents an eye position detection system under development to support the psychological analysis of a person. A way to detect eyeballs and their direction is presented. Apart from a small mention of C/C++, the use of support libraries, such as filters, image capture, etc., is not explicitly specified. It is mentioned that the response speed of the system has been considered, however, no evidence of this factor is presented. The data set on which the study was carried out is not mentioned, if it is pre-existing or was developed specifically for this work by the authors. No details of the faces in this data set (age, race, gender, etc.) are also presented. It is not specified whether the results obtained were reviewed by a professional from the clinical area and their conclusions. The references are very few in relation to the field of work developed.

This work shows the results of the development of a CBIR based on metric distance indices, comparing it with existing systems through retrieval accuracy and comparing the results of time efficiency for different indexing approaches such as GNAT, NAT, etc. The work addresses an important problem of recovery systems, its structure is correct and the results appear to be well founded. Perhaps the evaluation criteria are not sufficient to be able to determine the superiority of one approach over another, although the authors recognize the main shortcomings regarding this point and envision future work in this direction. The explanation of section 2.3, on precision, is unclear in defining how it is known in advance about the correct images most similar to a query in order to calculate precision. The time graphs in figure 3 do not indicate the scale.

The article deals with the construction of content-based image retrieval systems (of images), CBIR. The CBIR problem is introduced and some algorithms are presented that allow to speed up the search for nearest neighbors to an input vector (corresponding to an image) in the feature space chosen to represent the images. Color-, frequency-response-, and global-based features are used for each of the local frames into which an input image is divided. In this way, information of different types is introduced to the CBIR system to represent the images. - The article does not clearly define its contributions. It seems to add something in terms of the feature space in which the images are represented and it also seems to add something to the algorithms and data structures needed to speed up searches in metric spaces. - In general, the article uses little space to explain the proposed approach to CBIR (2 references to master's theses are given). Experimental results are presented in the conclusions, when clearly they should go in a previous section with the experiments. - Regarding the visual characteristics used to represent an image: Experiments are lacking that allow establishing what each of the characteristics proposed to use contributes. That is, I think it is important to answer the question: Why are you here and not others? and also to the question: Is any of them redundant and could it be stopped being used? Although it is true that a feature selection procedure is used, an experiment establishing the effect of the selection is missing. How much is gained in success rate over the use of the complete vector? It appears that the feature space after selection has dimension 3078 (section 2.4). Is it so or have the 3078 features been "manually" extracted? - The CBIR systems comparison experiment (section 2.3) is not understood. What is done with the 100 images common to databases? Is the same query made in all systems and is precision and recall measured using only the 100 common images when they appear or not in the system's response? That is not explained at all in the article. - When data such as sensitivity and specificity are given in the conclusions, it must be said on which data set it has been tested. It is possible to do a test on some data and obtain a completely different result on others. Therefore sensitivity and specificity without reference to the data from which it has been obtained are meaningless. - It seems to this reviewer that an article on CBIR should not overlook developments in Computer Vision based on (already classic) local features such as: Sivic, J. and Zisserman, A. Video Google: A Text Retrieval Approach to Object Matching in Videos Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision (2003) D. Nistér and H. Stewénius, Scalable recognition with a vocabulary tree Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (2006) - Some of the references, such as the [10,11,13], are incomplete. What do they mean? An article? An example system running on a URL? - The system working in the URL that the authors refer to gives execution errors when trying to test with images extracted from google images.

The publication aims to show the benefits of metric structures for image retrieval. This work is the continuation of several works already presented, such as. [1] "Parallel metric structures in image retrieval", Peña-Jaramillo, E. (Referenced in the paper) [2] "Definition of an Image Retriever based on Contents on Metric Spaces", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et to the. (Not referenced). [3] "Parallel Metric Structures in Image Retrieval on the Web", Eduardo Peña-Jaramillo, et al. (Not referenced). About reference number [1] it has not been possible to obtain an electronic copy, and from the aforementioned publications [2] and [3], it can be said that there is a new contribution in the experiments carried out on GNAT and Spaghetis structures. It must be explained in the publication that the work is not original from the author's point of view, and that its extension is based on the works [1], [2], [3] or another that is directly related to the work presented. . - The text is well structured and it is easy to understand what you want to expose. - Good presentation, no serious problems. Only improve the figures of the graphs, especially the accents, in matlab you can add text in latex to avoid this type of problem. The word "more" appears a couple of times without a tilde. - In the "Introduction" section, although the work is presented in a general way, I think it would be important to point out the state of the art in these matters. Are there related works? Are there important references? What is the contribution of the work to the state of the art?, etc. A more exhaustive bibliographic review is lacking. - In the "Feature Extraction" section I have found some details such as: - It has been difficult for me to find a definition on the layout technique since there is only one reference [1], so I suspect that the characteristics obtained from each sub-image as a signal which are mixed to obtain the vector that represents the total image, as it says in the text: "The union of all the extracted characteristics gives us as a result...", where it is not clear the type "join" that is performed. - The same thing also happens when the Fisher discriminant is referenced, again reference is made to [1]. A more relevant source should be added for this point. - The type of database used is not explained in detail. Is it public or private domain? What kind of images or groups of images it contains. How many are there per class? Are there repeated images? Quality of the images. The idea is to have a frame of reference so that anyone who wants to compare their algorithms with theirs can do so on equal terms. - From the images shown in figure 2, I can deduce that the database (I hope I am wrong) has repeated images, which can produce a bias when calculating the values of precision, sensitivity and specificity of the retrieved images. I believe that the ideal database to be able to correctly measure the quality of the recovery should have different images even if they have the same appearance, but never the same. Since when retrieving a set of images over a query image, if they are repeated, the number of true positives will be proportional to the repeated ones, which will result in a bias on the calculation of the metrics. Recommendations - In the text it is mentioned (conclusions section) that the solutions are not entirely satisfactory. I think there are currently projects like http://similar-images.googlelabs.com/, http://www.like.com/, http://www.tineye.com/, among others; that show great progress in this field and would be good to be reviewed. - On the other hand, regarding the set of features used, I recommend reviewing other types of features that have been shown to be invariant to scale and rotation. [4] "Distinctive Image Features from Scale-Invariant Keypoints". David G. Lowe. International Journal of Computer Vision, 2004. as well as its improvement [5] "SURF: Speeded Up Robust Features", Computer Vision and Image Understanding (CVIU). Herbert Bay, Andreas Ess, Tinne Tuytelaars, Luc Van Gool. Vol. 110, No. 3, pgs. 346--359, 2008.

The article promises to present a method to measure the quality of software development in SCRUM. I consider the proposal interesting and relevant, however the work has weaknesses in its construction. The promise of the title is diluted in the abstract and the introduction, with the “intro” of SPEM as a tool. Then, in the body of the article, the link between SPEM and the proposed quality measurement method is not clear. The case study on which they are basing their work is also unclear. Modeling in SPEM is about SCRUM in a theoretical way in about the case study. The evaluation of the method does not seem to measure the quality of the software, but the criteria of those involved with respect to adherence to the modeled process. And in any case, it always measures intermediate documents of the process and not defects or primary attributes of the quality of the software produced. Minor comments: - Review the construction of the references - The SCRUM modeling does not include the retrospective meeting. If you are modeling a particular SCRUM implementation, make it clear in the body of the paper. Otherwise it is a major modeling error. - Why do you use a traditional process to model an agile process? Couldn't one of the latter have been used? - On the first sheet, at the end of the first column, change the font.

RESUME. The work describes the steps to follow to apply fuzzy logic concepts in mobile devices. To exemplify the steps to follow, the author used a mobile robot called AMADEUS (similar to cleaning robots marketed in Japan [1]). To apply the concepts of fuzzy logic, the Mamdani module was used. General evaluation. The topic is extremely interesting and very recurrent lately. Devices that use fuzzy logic to operate is a very interesting and novel bridge between Artificial Intelligence and "pervasive computing". However, this work has at least one important weakness that should be resolved: 1) In the work it doesn't show why it is really important to use fuzzy logic. An example application is strongly recommended for the job. How would using fuzzy logic help on mobile devices? 2) At work it is not very clear to me if the use of fuzzy logic in mobile devices is something new in this area. If it is not something new, perhaps the work could become just a repetition of another work. If it's something new, please mention it. Minor Comments: - In the conclusions, the phrase "it was demonstrated" is mentioned; it is suggested to change to "showed". - Pay attention to the use of punctuations (eg "...", ".") and the use of capital letters. - At the end of the introduction, it is suggested to mention the structure of the document. The document tries to show an evaluation of software quality attributes based on the ISO 9126 standard. The document shows a proposal for a template with a series of questions to analyze the quality of different quality attributes of a developed software product. However, the document lacks structure. The writing is poor. In some parts of the document, the format parameters required in the authors' guide are not followed. For example, the abstract is centered and according to the event guide it must be justified. Some paragraphs of the document are presented in the same way. In terms of wording, the document is difficult to read, punctuation marks are missing or misplaced. The keywords do not match as article keywords. There is a lack of bibliographical references that support the affirmations that are made. Although the template can be as useful as they try to claim at work, it is necessary to look for a more consolidated validation that allows to ensure its usefulness. The statistics presented lack valid justifications and the presentation format is poor. Much of the document focuses on making claims described in the ISO 1926 standard and: 1. It is not properly cited as the main reference of the work. 2. Focusing the article to summarize the definition of each characteristic or sub-characteristic of the standard does not seem very appropriate for this type of work. The presentation format of the template lacks clarity. It seems that it is a questionnaire format but it is not shown as such. There is a list of unclear statements and questions. Some of these questions are mentioned in the results, however they do not appear in the list named by the author as "template", it is the case of: Does the system operate together with another system? In general terms, the work must refine much more.

The article presents a case study of the application of a template to measure quality according to the ISO 9126 standard. Although it is true that it fits the scope of the event and its proposal may be of interest to software engineers who wish to have some practical instrument to apply in their quality systems, the work has serious deficiencies that must be improved to be published. The technical presentation of the document has shortcomings that do not meet the standards established for writing the article. In particular, we can mention a few: - The format is not uniform, as can be seen in the abstract, which has different settings in its extension. There are also differences in spacing after each paragraph. Sometimes it exists and sometimes it doesn't. The bullets have different indentations. Bibliographical references have different indentations. - The most serious is spelling and writing. The document requires a major editing review. In just the first 2 paragraphs of the introduction I have found more than 5 faults. Regarding its structure, I think it should be reorganized to improve its presentation. I think the objectives should go inside the introduction. The presentation of the ISO criteria should be summarized in a descriptive table. It's annoyingly long and I think it can be referenced for details. On the other hand, I think it should be clarified if the template is pre-existing or is a proposal of the work, in which case it should be highlighted since it would be the main contribution of the article. Your presentation is unfortunate. I think it should be summarized in a table and clearly state what can be answered. Most are not even presented as questions. I insist that if the template is the contribution it should be made easier for other engineers to use. Your presentation does not help this. (eg the first, "When interacting with the system, notice how predictable it is": what do I say?) The instrument should be self-contained so that it clearly contains guidance for its application. Furthermore, it doesn't provide clarity on how I combine query responses to get a quality metric. I think there is too much work left for the reader. The results are not presented in a readable way. I think a table would help. It even mentions several times the tabulation of the results but this does not appear. As it is a case study, I would like to see in that table the answers that were obtained and how the percentages that measure quality were calculated.

First, the impact factor of the publications has not been considered, thus the development associated with this type of review has been dismissed, mixing high-impact works (for example, journal articles ISIs impact factor >2, such as MISQ) with works without a quality review (example, what Scholar "launches" just for matching in the search). Second, it is said that references from 2008 onwards will be taken as a priority, but many of its references are from before that date, and this is not uncommon, since between 2001 and 2004 there is an explosion of work in this specific field. Third, papers from conferences in the area of high impact in the scientific community such as AMCIS or ECIS have not been explicitly included (the former has a private database, not accessible by Google, and the latter is free). - The aforementioned limitations restrict the scope of the interesting results presented in the work.

RESUME. The work proposes a model to evaluate the quality of agent-oriented software. Basically, the model considers three properties to evaluate its quality: social ability, autonomy and proactivity. To evaluate these properties, the author breaks these properties down into several measurable sub-properties. The author evaluates this model through a case study: a banking system. General Comments: Notarially, the structure of the document has the necessary aspects to be considered a scientific article. The contribution of the article seems to be relevant. That said, this work lacks some points that (for me) are important to address: * The author mentions that there is no model to evaluate the quality of agent software, and he proposes one. His proposal is an adaptation of ISO/IEC, however, the author does not justify why it is appropriate. * Regarding the previous point, paragraph 1 of the introduction says that there is no model that measures the quality of software. Then paragraph 2 mentions that there are some works about this. The author should clarify his contribution. * The author mentions that software was developed for this work, however, this work is listed as yet another publication (and by another author). If the mentioned software is not part of the contributions of the work, please delete these sentences. Other comments: * In the case study section it is not so easy to understand. The work presents an interesting proposal to evaluate the agent-oriented software development paradigm and although it is a work in progress, it has good foundations. RESUME. This work describes three teaching activities in an elective course at the University of La Serena. Developing interpreters using the ANTLR tool on Android is the main connection of these activities. The first activity implements a parser/interpreter for a calculator. The second activity incorporates the ability to sort lists in the interpreter. The last activity incorporates the voice recognition service using a Google library. According to the work, the result of these activities allowed students to better understand the concepts of formal languages. General Evaluation: The work describes very clearly how the activities were carried out in the elective course. However, from my point of view, the work has 2 major weaknesses: 1) The main motivation of the work is that the use of ANTLR tools is useful for formal language courses. However, a sample of why this statement is true is never offered, only how to implement the activity software is detailed. It is strongly recommended to give real signs (eg justifications, experiments, etc.) of why these tools help the teaching of these topics. 2) This point is the cause of the previous point. There is no motivation or problem that clearly shows the need to use these tools for a language course. If the authors manage to find a clear and measurable motivation, point 1) can be solved. Finally, the work fails to convince with its conclusion. Minor comments: 1) The work exceeds the maximum required number of pages (9 (>8) pages). 2) In the conclusion it is stated that with the use of ANTLR in Android and the knowledge of formal languages it is possible to match the tools of Siri (Apple) & Google Now. In my opinion, that statement is not true, because to solve the activities they use Google APIs, meaning that without Google products, these activities cannot be carried out. While this article shows a fair amount of work, it is cryptically written and it is very difficult to see where it is leading. "handle the CAP theorem"... the theorem says that there are three features that cannot occur simultaneously, so "handle" doesn't make sense. "denormalize the data, that is, the ACID properties (atomicity, consistency, isolation and durability) are sacrificed for performance reasons...", I do not see a direct relationship between denormalize (a design aspect) with the acid properties (a set of transaction properties). The article describes very well the DBMS for mobile phones, as well as some database engines with non-relational technology known as NoSQL, in a context of data storage in the cloud or cloud-computing. It makes a good comparison of the technical characteristics of some DB managers in this area (table 3). It proposes a methodology, apparently to define and carry out an experiment that allows evaluating and comparing BD of this type, as defined in the title of the article. However, it only manages to establish a simple and qualitative comparison of components and other aspects such as services (table 4). There is no evidence of a quantitative and objective comparison, at the level of performance and with data, transactions and processing times that really allow us to sustain, as it does without these variables, which DB is more efficient compared to another. The abstract does not confirm or identify the complete work. The conclusions are drawn based on the characteristics and not on comparative tests of performance. In summary, it is a work from the point of view that it would be a contribution if it formalized the methodology and described the quantitative application of an experimentation that really allows DBMS to be compared in a cloud-computing context. It is suggested to complement it with a controlled experiment with test data and transaction records and measure variables, obtain objective statistics that allow evaluating the performance of mobile DB and NoSQL systems, under clearly defined conditions and parameters and in the same environmental conditions. (bandwidth, transaction rates, data volume, equipment, etc.).

column10: It is a work of which only the information collection stage and its summary have been carried out.
column11: The article presents a review of mobile DBMS and NoSQL. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the work is rather descriptive and lacks experimental results. What he indicates on page 8, methodology, considers 2 phases, of which only the results of the first phase are apparently presented. It is suggested to carry out the second phase, which involves an experimental work of data collection and analysis, and then generate an article with these results.

The article describes a set of data extraction techniques mainly found in ETL tools, it mentions the social ne2rks that it initially indicates as data sources for a study, but that definitely does not apply or at least does not show its application and results, the same it happens with the NoSQL databases that it mentions but that it is observed and a work with them is described. I would suggest taking advantage of this preliminary review to propose a methodology for working on social ne2rks, in addition to establishing the steps to follow in this methodology for an efficient extraction of data from the repositories of social ne2rks indicated, perhaps comparing the performance and usefulness of the techniques in each social ne2rk and evaluate which ETL techniques are more appropriate but empirically. It should also be noted that it has some writing errors, repetition of articles and words.

The article does not fully reflect what is indicated in the title "Review of information extraction techniques in social ne2rks on NoSQL databases", since it is only a general look at social ne2rks and the data persistence systems they use. (based on sabd noSQL). More than extraction techniques, the well-known ETL process used in Datawarehouse is reviewed, proposing its use in social ne2rks. Drafting (review page numbering): (page 2) "from the world of data" (page 5) "that although they are free with the main purpose of collecting personal data from users"

The work is interesting. It is noted that considerable time was invested in the bibliographic review of the subject. The contribution is that it allows reviewing information extraction techniques for noSQL databases. Once the techniques are applied, new challenges will be found that can only be "seen" at the time of implementation. On the other hand, the risk lies in how many researchers are working on the subject in different places. This is because it is a mainline theme. What is implemented in this regard? Is it worth applying the techniques? A look at these aspects is important so as not to find surprises in the implementation. The work is well presented and clear. However, in the writing they are associated with "2. Data preparation". What activity is 1 or 2 associated with?

column10: Although the article is easy to read and follow, in substance it lacks a better supported comparison than just a case study illustration.
column11: This article presents a comparison, based on a list of criteria, of 2 database approaches: relational vs. temporary. The article generally has a logical order and is readable. However, the comparison has at least 2 drawbacks: 1) there is a lack of information on how the results of tables 3 and 4 were obtained. There must be a sufficiently detailed description to be able to replicate the work later. 2) The case study presented forms the basis of the comparison. A real comparison must be based on a variety of cases and domains, in order to conclude on a broader basis. I suggest addressing these 2 aspects first to better support the results and conclusions.

The text needs to be revised, there are long sentences (for example the second of the second paragraph of the introduction has 11 lines) and missing or incorrectly placed punctuations. The first sentence of the second paragraph of the introduction. Also include the meaning of the acronyms PLC and PC.

This work offers a comparative analysis of the use of wired technology and programmed technology. The scope of "related work" presented in the document is non-existent. In this context, it is not possible to determine if the comparison criteria suggested in the work are, in fact, the pertinent ones to carry out an evaluation. The criteria for comparing technologies are in some cases objective and in other cases subjective. In this sense, the work does not suggest how to face the assessment of each criterion to finally make a comparison (for example, in the "security" item or in the "programming" item). There are grammatical problems (for example, "high time"). Additionally, the work is poorly organized, making it difficult to understand due to the low effort to locate the content of the tables in a legible way. A real contribution of this work is not displayed. "Rexroth Bosch Group" is cited on numerous occasions, without adding much more at each point The impact and relevance of this work, in terms of novelty, is not observable.

Although the subject of automation is of interest, in this article it has a very general approach, it would be interesting, for example, to refer to compact PLCs vs. Modular PLCs could also be included in the comparison with high-end microcontrollers, since by providing them with a power stage, very interesting application results can be achieved at low cost. The title tends to confuse since the presentation of the latest technologies used in industrial automation is expected and rather it focuses first on a historical review of the advances in the area and then dedicates itself to comparing only 2 of the existing types of controllers. in the industry. The exposed content is frequently found in the literature referring to the area, so it does not represent, in my opinion, a relevant contribution to the subject.

column11: The article presents an application of pattern recognition techniques to the classification of wood types based on audio recordings. Some English terms are also presented that should be replaced by their meaning in Spanish (eg test). Equations 4 and 5 contain errors and need to be better explained. Also adjust the font size. Table 1 contains redundant information, since the quantities presented seem to be independent of the method. Improve the resolution and increase the size of figure 5 (that occupies the 2 columns), since it is not possible to appreciate the different points and clusters that are commented on. In the substantive aspects: The review of the state of the art is weak, and more relevant current references related to pattern recognition based on audio data should be incorporated (although not necessarily in the domain of woodwinds). The version of the KNN algorithm whose pseudocode is shown is incorrect. It should be reviewed and corrected. It is not appreciated that it works for a given K. Recursion is also not appreciated. More information and detail of the data and the derived characteristics are required.

The work presents an algorithmic method for the classification of the quality of wood related to electricity poles and railway tracks. This work is interesting, but its writing does not allow a fluid and clear reading of it. What the article should improve is: - Improve the writing of the summary. The summary indicates the test to test the hypothesis, but it does not indicate what the hypothesis is. - Eliminate statements without references, such as: 'The defects that occur ... significant frequency' - An statement is made that is ambiguous with respect to the work: 'the audio signals of the wood present the difficulty of not having well-defined information. ..' and '...with the blow of the hammer it can be more or less difficult to determine if...'. So how were the features obtained? Problems of organization of the paper The work is very focused on describing "functionalities" of a system, and not the contribution itself compared to the state of the art.

The work addresses the problem of autonomous navigation of mobile robots by defining a reactive control architecture. Authors need to be clearer on why to use a reactive architecture, relative to other available approaches. It is necessary to improve the readability of the equations. The work is correct and pertinent. The field of mobile robotics has multiple applications. It is necessary to incorporate some guidelines on future work.

do not agree with what is written in the second paragraph of the introduction. The contribution of the research, nor the results, are not clear.
