It seems to me an interesting article to be considered, although the final objective of it is somewhat obscure: "to measure the position of a robot on a soccer field". In particular, it is not clear if the work is oriented towards a later more ambitious goal (multiple robots, equipment movement in real time, and what to finally do with this data???). From what can be deduced, although it is not explicitly said, measurements were made of "a" robot "locating" it in different positions in the field, but not with it moving in real time. Thus, results are presented that could have been obtained with another, more classic configuration of the computer vision area (the contribution of the robot and the soccer field, at least until now, do not have a fundamental relevance in the work developed). Finally, it does not seem to me that the results obtained are strictly new, but even so, it can be an attractive experience to be known.

The paper presents a survey of 2 mining companies on the architecture stage of the IT outsourcing process. The work is exploratory and therefore its contribution is limited since no results have been presented yet. I think that in this state it is unsuitable for the conference where the presentation of results and research contributions are expected. The document needs to be improved in terms of its wording.

The name of the article is “How does it affect….”, and it indicates in its Summary “… applied through a case study to 2 mining companies in the Antofagasta region and to a supplier-type company”. However, the article does not present a section with the indicated case study, which indicates that it is not possible to answer the question expressed in the title of the article. Therefore, what is expressed is good intentions, but there is no empirical evidence. The topic is very important, the form of solution is also adequate, but everything is expressed in theoretical terms. It is indicated that "the investigation is currently in the stage of conducting interviews", therefore, no analysis of the data or results and conclusions has been carried out. The Results section does not present results. It will be an interesting article when all the stages of the proposed methodology are fulfilled. Some minor observations and/or comments: - References [6] and [13] were not used in the text. - The first paragraph of the State of the Art is a repetition of the second paragraph of the Introduction. - On page 3, change “key activities” to “key activities”. - The Figure on page 6 has no title.

The article presents an introduction to the investigation of the effect of IT Outsourcing in mining in the second region, but does not show concrete results. In the same article it is indicated that the investigation is not finished. It would be interesting to have the full analysis of the results.

The article has 2 main contributions: a discussion about the usefulness of SCADA controls on mobile devices, a description of some of the specific applications that implement this function on cell phones or tablets. There are several typos throughout the article. For example separators are used at the end of sentence _, but not consistently. The first and last sentences of the abstract seem poorly worded. In the final paragraphs of the introduction the lists are not clearly explained. Although it is relevant for the conference to make a review of mobile SCADA applications, a search mechanism is not defined, nor a criterion to compare them. What are their differences? Which one is suitable in each case? It is suggested to include a comparative table of its benefits, and more importantly, define comparison criteria to be able to provide new data to the reader. The conclusions return to the introduction but do not answer which applications should be used in the context of the mining industry.

The article presents a theoretical analysis on SCADA systems. There is no evidence on the application in a case study. The Abstract is not adequate, neither is the introduction. The Results section and the Conclusions section do not present contributions for a scientific article or one that shows business experiences in ICT applications. References [3], [5] and [7] are from the same author, same title and same date. The same goes for References [4] and [6]. Reference [1] is not used in the text.

The application of SCADA systems for mining is somewhat interesting, but the work is only limited to mentioning mobile tools and there is no clear point of comparison between them. The specific contribution of these tools in a real mining process is also unclear. There are consistency issues in the abstract and introduction. The conclusions are not convincing enough, plus there are some drafting problems.

The work presents a state of the art regarding UWSN underwater sensor ne2rks and underwater autonomous mobile robotics. In particular, it describes the problem presented, providing topologies, strategies and hardware for communication. The text is very descriptive, not very analytical and critical, generating little contribution and value, beyond a bibliographic compilation.

The work consists of an article type survey or study of the subject on underwater ne2rks and vehicles, bibliographic review and related technology very interesting and complete in my opinion. I suggest that you could provide a contribution based on this study, for example by providing a taxonomy of the characteristics of the technologies required for this type of problem-solution pair, and adding a proposal through an implementation and testing methodology. The above is indicated as a delivery in future work, perhaps at least it should have delivered a comparative table of the associated and described technologies.

column10: It is a good article, preliminary, since it is dedicated to describing technology and topology, with tests without hard data... it is new, so its acceptance is suggested.
column11: It is a good work, well written, it deals with a new topic in aquatic sensor ne2rks, it will report the tests in more detail and the effectiveness in the application.

The article presents an experiment that compares different navigation architectures for a mobile robot. The architectures (algorithms, approaches) used are described, as well as the metrics defined to evaluate navigation performance. The results are statistically analyzed using analysis of variance. The article is well written and the experiment is clearly presented. The bibliographical references seem to be adequate. In the introduction, the comparison objectives are correctly justified and the possible approaches for the navigation of a robot are described in a general way. The selection of metrics is justified and tries to go beyond a combination of simple measurements. The experiment is well described, although it could be explained why other obstacle configurations were not included in the observation. Statistical methods (analysis of variance) are applied correctly, although an analysis of normality in the distribution could be included. One of the weak points of the work is that a deeper discussion of the results is needed. Beyond indicating that one of the architectures has better performance, the reasons should be discussed and new conjectures made. The generalization of the results and the discussion of threats to validity should be part of the discussion. For example: What kind of obstacles does each algorithm work on? What is the programming effort of each of the architectures? What are the robot's high-level navigation goals (deliberative behavior)?

The interest caused by the problem of robot navigation is undeniable, so the presented work constitutes an alternative for the choice of the control architecture, since it presents us with a possible solution to the problem through the comparison of metrics, however it must Bear in mind that it has been carried out in a simulation environment, under certain conditions that will not necessarily be replicated in practice, which in my opinion restricts the scope of application of the results obtained. On the other hand, the references and development of statistical calculations give validity to the results obtained with the consideration of the environment in which the test was carried out. Work well developed, although there is a need to carry out tests with the real mobile, under various conditions of the robot's environment, to validate the results obtained in the simulator.

The work compares four autonomous navigation architectures for mobile robots, pure reactive architectures, neural ne2rks, fuzzy logic and a neuro-fuzzy hybrid architecture. The work is well planned, the experimental work seems replicable and the results presented sound coherent. The main aspect to improve would be the analysis/discussion of the results, which can be further developed.

The article presents a research plan that proposes to combine the theoretical constructs of competencies for technology management (with the BTM model) and the perception of professional success (with a proposed model that combines several factors from various sources). IT management capacity is a key element for professionals in the area and not only their technological skills. It seems relevant to study how these competencies impact professional success, or, at least, on the subjective perception of said success. The study contains references to relevant sources, although it is suggested to reduce the number and prioritize in the case of articles in journals or conferences. Although the topic is relevant, there are some risks in the definition of the constructs that are not analyzed. What are the limits between the perception of professional and personal success? Is it possible to carry out a study of the perception of professional success only considering the BTM model and leaving out technological skills? Does the study apply to all IT professionals or only to those who manage technology projects as CIOs? The main weakness of the research is that it is identified as an experimental method, when in reality the survey does not have the degree of control over the object of study to be classified in this way. There is also talk of a causality study, but the survey would only allow a co-relationship study. About the survey it is explained which are the evaluated factors and the Likert scale. However, there are no examples of specific questions and an explanation of how they will be answered by the subjects. For example: Is it feasible for a person to assess your commitment or leadership? Although the relationship is being evaluated in general terms and not in terms of its own, it would be advisable to carry out a validation of the model first and then the survey itself with a group of experts or managers of IT professionals.

The article shows the design of a research on the impact of IT skills on the perception of professional success, but it is not what it says in its title. There is a section corresponding to an extensive review of previous work and definitions, compared to the section showing the research design, which is quite brief. In my opinion, it was convenient to have presented the article as a systematic review of the existing literature on the subject in order to find gaps and/or similarities in the research design, or to have placed more emphasis on the latter. Although the topic may be new, the article does not demonstrate it, since it is only the presentation of a research design. In the conclusions section, no specific conclusions are shown from the work carried out, only possible scenarios of future work are proposed. Regarding the form, the article is well structured, but there are details to be corrected: - abuse of "IT" - in some paragraphs previous works are indicated without being referenced - the figure of the model is very basic (it is not a contribution ) - paragraphs not aligned (justified) - figure 1 should have been a table - error in the correlation of figures

It is an interesting topic, but the author indicates that the research is in the data collection phase and that there are about 7 months left to obtain the final results. However, the theoretical analysis carried out is quite important. Figure 3 is very simple. I suggest that the proposed model provides more information. The name of the author and institution should be anonymous (according to congress regulations). On page 5, you should check that the text is right-justified. On page 8, change “be capable” to “be capable”.

I find it an interesting job, with an emphasis on covering practical gaps. Its content and structure are technically well presented. However, on the other hand, there is no clear distinction between previous work and the original proposal of this work. The article states that there are previous works regarding this CMMI-ÄGIL pairing but it does not indicate whether these proposals are sufficient or insufficient for improvement. That is, the motivation or justification for this work is not explicit.

The article makes a general description of the CMMI model and agile methodologies, taking Scrum and XP as particular cases. A discussion is made on the combination of these approaches for process improvement, mapping the REQM and PPQA process areas with their equivalents in agile methodologies. The article makes correct general descriptions of the methodologies, but does not contain novel research elements that contribute to knowledge in this area. For the technical/scientific community of software engineering it is evident that the approaches have different starting points, but they are combinable. This is especially true for software process improvement experts. The review that is done on the research of the combination of agility and CMMI is not systematic. By state of the art we do not mean a simple description of each approach, but rather collect the most up-to-date research on this topic. Although it may be interesting to map between process areas and agile practices, it is not explained what steps are going to be followed to do this. Nor is there a validation of this mapping or an explanation of how it can be applied, for example by a process improvement consultant. No empirical evidence of the applicability or usefulness of mapping is provided.

The article presents a description of the integration between CMMI and agile development methods. An emphasis made by the authors is that this integration is recommended for SMEs. Software development for the smallest companies is an unsolved challenge. As such, the authors take a topic that is interesting and well justify the idea of the topic. However, I think they fail to develop their point in the way that would be expected from a scientific point of view. Although the authors indicate that they do a review of the literature, this is not adequately achieved, since a systematic review methodology of this goal is not observed. On the other hand, the article in my opinion makes a suitable summary for people who do not belong to the area but are familiar with some key concepts described in the paper. It is worth mentioning that it seems to me to be a well-written and planned article, in general, with an easy-to-understand structure. In addition, another criticism I would make is that although the ideas of CMMI and agile development seem well described to me, the same does not happen with respect to adequately justifying their specific application in SMEs. I think the article could be substantially improved. One suggestion I would make for this would be the presentation of a case that strengthens the central argument of the article, that is, CMMI and agile development are compatible and especially useful for SMEs. In this way, less emphasis could be given to the revision (which seems insufficient in that sense) and the practical relevance of the argument would be raised. If so, the article could have an interesting projection. In addition, the inclusion of references should be improved since there are a large number of arguments that deserve to be clarified if they belong to an opinion of the authors or are extracted from existing theory. There are very minor spelling and grammatical errors.

Abstract: The article seeks to analyze the existing collaboration ne2rks between Information Systems (IS) researchers in Chile and Latin America. The co-authors of research published in Contecsi and Infonor are used to carry out an analysis of social ne2rks, explaining the latter. Three questions are raised that are answered later in the analysis of the results through tables and graphs; concluding several similarities between communities and that there is collaboration between IS researchers, which is unfortunately mostly intra-institutional. Evaluation: The work is well done. It presents a clear and concise structure that helps the reader understand the ideas being discussed. It is an interesting work that belongs to a process that is not yet finished due to the scarcity and continuity of data. The first caused by registry problems and normalization of published papers, and the second due to the fact that there will be new versions of the congresses that will deliver new data. Even so, it is possible to identify some problems, these are: 1) There is no argument based on data as to why these are the 2 congresses chosen, given that these congresses are small. 2) Being a work of a small scope (with respect to the congresses used), the usefulness of the result is also small. Minor comment: There is an error in the numbering of the pages.

The work exposes in a clear way and with good arguments an analysis of the collaboration between different researchers and institutions. The contribution made is interesting, first as an identification of opportunities for improvement in joint work, and second, as an analysis of the local publication. It would be interesting to apply the same methodology to other congresses in the area, whether Chilean or Latin American, and see the results obtained.

Although it is true that the work is well structured and shows signs of an adequate methodology, the usefulness of the study carried out is not clear. The results obtained and presented are based on a very short study period, which removes confidence from the conclusions. There are some small editing and writing errors in the text. It is recommended to expand the input data set of the study.

It seems to me an interesting work, mainly because it provides empirical evidence on co-creation techniques. Its content and structure are technically well presented. However, the work has relevant omissions to assess its scientific contribution. For example, it does not present statistical analysis of the data thrown. It only exposes a distribution of the results without showing statistical significance. I also miss a section (or in the conclusions) on limitations to the validity of the experiment. I think it has several threats to validity that haven't been addressed. To name a few: it is not explained if the assignment to the groups was random; the time of the sessions is different; learning in previous sessions, etc. Other suggestions: p. 1 Title I think the title is not appropriate. It does not represent the core of the work, which is an experiment. P. 4 Second column Errors in bullet format p. 4 Third bullet point second column every TIME p. 5 Last bullet first column parentheses

The article is about collaboration in the creation of content through social ne2rks. The article is well structured and with some writing details. The bibliography does not comply with the format required by the congress. Regarding the topic of the article, initially there was a doubt about whether the article was relevant for the congress, since it was an experiment on the social behavior of some individuals through social ne2rks. Later, when reviewing the experiment, it can be seen that the relevance is in the perspective of education in computer engineering. Therefore, I recommend that the summary be modified in the article, mentioning the scope of the experiment so that the reader, from the beginning, has greater knowledge about the article. In addition, for greater relevance with the congress, it is recommended to place greater emphasis on collaboration for the development of some tasks typical of the discipline, such as the analysis and/or design of systems. Finally, the article is innovative in the way of how to perform some tasks through social ne2rks.

This article presents the results of an experiment where it is evident that co-creation techniques applied through social ne2rks and using mobile devices can enhance the creativity of the participants. It is an interesting topic and I think it can be a contribution to the congress. The presentation of the article should be improved. Some observations and/or comments: - The first 2 paragraphs of the Introduction are almost the entire Summary. - On page 4, change “every time” to “every time”. - On page 5, Step 3, you don't close parentheses twice. - I suggest enlarging Figure 2. - I consider it excessive to use a page for a single figure. - In Reference [11], correct “Conference on the, 2009” - Page number 3 is repeated three times. - After page 7, continue with page 3. - Reference [4] says “2004b”

The paper has the sections Introduction, Theoretical Analysis, Results, and Conclusions. The paper is poorly structured. In the Theoretical Analysis section, basic concepts and methodological aspects are mixed. The Results section of a case study that is nowhere defined. Subsequently, an analysis in words of results is carried out on an experimental situation that is not described in detail either, which guarantees a minimum experimental replicability. Finally, the Acknowledgments section is highly informal. The writing does not follow the usual canon of papers (writing in the third person), but is presented in the first person. Substantial improvement in the order and presentation of each section is required. In summary, the paper suggests the idea that the implementation of safety instrumented systems is vital to improve the safety and quality of processes in the industry. However, no models, experiences, concrete empirical results or any other equivalent are proposed. There are no real reasons to propose the acceptance of this work.

The paper presents a research focused on evaluating the impact of safety instrumented systems on the processes to which they are applied. The number of references is poor, considering the nature of the research. The use of references in the introductory section is especially scarce. Also, the introduction does not make very clear the contribution of the research or the methodology used, both should be part of this section in a concise manner. The use of first person plural in the writing should be avoided (eg, 3rd paragraph of the "theoretical analysis" section). Put references inside the paragraph, not outside (e.g., paragraph "Security measures", "... started. [7]", should be "... started [7]". This is repeated elsewhere of the document Typing error in the first paragraph of the 3rd page Inconsistent reference format (second paragraph in "Remaining risk accepted") Also misuse of punctuation (First paragraph of the 4th page) About the results, these are not clear. The research question is poorly or ambiguously posed. Based on this, it is impossible to understand the contribution or the proposed approach. This, added to the scarce theoretical framework provided, does not justify the relevance of the research presented. The conclusions do not refer to any aspect of research or future work The format of the references should be reviewed For all the reasons stated above, the work is not of sufficient quality to be accepted.

This article presents a "state of the art" in cooperative systems with multiple robots. From this perspective, it is a properly written disclosure article that, from the point of view of the bibliography, includes current references. It is complex to make an evaluation of an article of this type for its contribution, although it would have been appropriate to provide some final by-product, such as a comparative table or some evaluation (application areas?) based on the research work.

The work presents a study of the state of the art regarding multi-robot cooperative robotics systems. The focus of the review is the control architecture present in those systems. The abstract in English should be revised in its wording, especially the use of words, such as "giving"->"providing", "panoramic"->"general", etc. The introduction does not provide a major contribution to the structure of the document. A little is said about the research associated with the topic, but with a very low use of references and the section ends abruptly without explaining the methodology or contributions of the work. The work delivers a very unclear "problem statement" that does not provide greater relevance. Moreover, in addition to identifying some approaches to the context, the work does not propose any solution, alternative, categorization, framework or contribution in general to the (unclear) problem presented. In summary, the work performs a relatively adequate collection of information regarding multi-robot cooperative robotics systems, however, beyond that, a real contribution or relevance from the scientific point of view of the work is not revealed. If these points were clearer, if the methodology were presented directly, and if a specific research product were presented, this work could be accepted, but in its current state it is not recommended.

The work presents a method for detecting fractures in well images. The work, in general, is very unconvincing for several reasons: 1.- It spends a LOT of space describing the fundamentals but not comparing and/or discussing with the state of the art. There are MANY adaptive methods of image classification, and the problem at hand is nothing different except a different application. 2.- The hypothesis is not clear, so the contribution of the work cannot be measured. 3.- The detection method described only defines mathematical formulas for the geometric characterization of the fractures. This is a fairly unrobust procedure and, furthermore, the results evaluating the method are not convincing either in the standard metrics used (accuracy, error, ROC curve, etc). 4.- The experimental methodology is very weak, neither does it compare the method with the state of the art, nor does it use standard metrics to analyze the precision/accuracy of the method.

This work shows the procedure proposed for the automatic detection of fractures in wells. The methodology looks novel and interesting. The article shows the methodology well and is well written, but at the end of the article a better presentation of the results in real wells is missing. The contribution of the article is not clear, first it indicates that it is automatic detection and in another part it indicates that it is the modification of the algorithm. You should improve the presentation of the results in real wells and compare it with the desired and perhaps with the results of applying other techniques.

The paper describes the current context of the use of available technologies to automatically control the dosage of macronutrients in soilless crop treatments. The work is pertinent in its definition and development. However, the title induces an expectation that the document fails to satisfy. The paper offers a discussion about the state of the art in technology for the problem addressed, however, it does not offer a comparative framework, selection criteria, or suggestions on good practices. As a first approach to the research area it is pertinent, however, some more own work should be added to the paper.

The article carries out an interesting bibliographic study on AI technology applied in the field of fertigation and nutrient dosage for soilless crops. It does not establish or describe the design of a solution on a case study, and only remains in the preliminary study. So the title “Design and Construction of an Automatic System….” It does not correspond, and it would have to be oriented to what it describes, that is to say something like: "Analysis and study of automatic systems..." It is an interesting survey article but it contradicts the title and the introduction, the conclusions are also not consistent to this type of work, they should be more ad-hoc with comparative variables.

The title of the work induces the reader to expect to find the design and implementation of an irrigation control system, however as the reading of the document deepens, this becomes increasingly distant, since the author proposes a review of various results of work carried out by third parties in a kind of compilation of information regarding the subject, to finally propose from his point of view which of these results could be considered of interest depending on the type of crop. It is necessary to modify the name of the article since it misleads the reader, because at the end of reviewing the document, the design and less the construction of the irrigation system have not been obtained as a result, only alternatives have been obtained to consider depending on various factors. . Perhaps it is necessary to focus on a specific type of crop to carry out in detail the design and implementation of the irrigation system in order to carry out tests that validate the work carried out.

The article describes an interesting control application of a physical device (for the case under study, a Lego Mindstorms mobile robot), by processing the signals derived from changes of a facial and/or mental nature, coming from an Emotiv EEG helmet. , which performs a high-resolution electroencephalogram. However, despite the interest of the work presented, the article lacks the rigor that characterizes the methodological research process, a critical bibliographic discussion is not observed, there is no clear definition of the problem to be investigated, it presents a poor discussion of results and abundant formatting errors (e.g. page 3 presents the following text "Error! The source of the reference is not found", page 2 does not exist, etc.), which denote that the author was not rigorous in his revision before sending . Finally, in my opinion, the work is a good contribution as an excellent project or workshop work within the curriculum of a Computer Science or Electronics career.

column11: The document offers a comparison regarding the application of algorithms for impulsive noise removal in 2 types of hardware architectures: GPU and CPU. The document in general is poorly written, especially from page 4 onwards. The abstract of the work is adequate, however its wording must be reviewed, for example. the use of commas. The introduction starts by talking about (i) image processing, in the middle (ii) what is done in this work is pointed out and then continues with (iii) a comparison between GPU and CPU. This structure is not suitable, it should be i-iii-ii, or just move iii to later sections and leave i-ii. In addition to that, not much is said about the experimental design and the results obtained, things that should be included in the introduction. Page 3 has a large blank space that needs to be fixed. The section "A. Review phase" does not have much value as an independent section, since it mentions something that is natural in a study of this type, which is the bibliographic review. It would look much better to join it with the next section (B). the section "D. Artifacts resulting from the project" speaks of "research results", but only aspects of the built software plus a results spreadsheet are mentioned, however results directly associated with the research are not observed. Page 5 has another blank space. In general, the presentation of results is poor. There is no table clearly indicating the results and the graphs presented do not look good. The analysis of the results is adequate but lacks depth and relevance regarding what exactly is to be compared in both architectures. The images are not used or explained in the comparison. The article seeks to summarize and review point cloud filtering and segmentation algorithms in computer vision. In the words of the authors "The objective of this work is to carry out a review of the state of the art regarding the treatment of point clouds". In my opinion it does not achieve this objective declared by them. My reasons are stated below. First, it is noteworthy that as an article that pretends to establish the state of the art, it has a very scarce bibliography (14 articles). In that sense, it would be more appropriate to indicate that this work is of a preliminary nature (if that is the case) since in this way such a low number of reviewed articles would be justified. Second, and what seems to me to be of greater relevance, the work does not make an adequate summary of the bibliography, but rather it seems to be a note on some filtering and segmentation methods. A review of the state of the art, in my opinion, should have a purpose such as identifying the main gaps in the literature or research opportunities. Third, although a literature review is essentially an abstract, it must be systematic. That is, it must have a method that has to be specified. For example, what was the search equation used and what was the time range and selection criteria of the reviewed articles or which were eliminated and why. Finally, although it has nothing to do with the content or the objective of the article, there are obvious formatting problems. For example, the entire conclusion section is centered rather than justified. In addition, there are drafting problems that in some parts make it difficult to understand the text. For example, the first paragraph in the "Segmentation" subsection says "The process of generating a surface model from a cloud of points, the segmentation that extracts the edges and partitions of the 3D world, the points play an important role in the fitting of The surfaces." There are also misspellings such as writing "laser" and "laser" in different parts of the document. In summary, the article does not achieve its objective of being a review of the state of the art and, in addition, it has obvious formatting errors.

The work presents a research in development related to the cost of contracting IT services for organizations, specifically a case study in the Chilean Mining Industry is proposed. The work is focused on a business case, however, although the document emphasizes the theoretical compilation of the concepts associated with the financial and cost aspects of contracted IT services, the case study is not clear and the article seems incomplete. The structure of the document generates confusion because in the introduction objectives associated with the case study are established, but at the end of the document the results are not presented because the research is in progress. It is suggested to limit the article and structure it better, in such a way that the preliminary results obtained up to the point where the research project is found can be presented, that is, a conceptual review of financial aspects for IT Services, without generating expectations regarding to the development of statistics or analysis of costs that have not yet been calculated. In order to have a strong emphasis on reviewing concepts, the article is sparsely referenced. It is recommended to improve the concepts and the conceptual basis from a comprehensive literature review that allows to base the research and present partial results of the review of concepts. There are marked deficiencies in the drafting of the document. Letters are missing from the abstract and punctuation marks are not clear. In paragraphs like the first of the second column on page 3, it is difficult to understand the idea and that makes it difficult to read the document. In sections defining concepts such as IT Costs (page 3) it is necessary to refer to the conceptual statements (fundamental basis of the article). It is recommended to take into account the terms in English to unify the way of citing terms or concepts. Some cannot be translated, but it is advisable to handle concepts in only one language. In addition, it is advisable to define the objective of the article and focus it on a single purpose. That is, if you want to present the methodology for the design of the research, emphasis should be placed on it. Or, if what you want is to emphasize the calculations established or designed by means of the tool, then focus the article on this objective. As a general recommendation, it is suggested to focus the article on a conceptual review of the financial costs of contracting IT services in Chilean companies, taking into account that the research is at an early stage.

column11: ABSTRACT: The work presents and describes the application of a social ne2rk for news (4x4News), where the most relevant news will be present (among other features). What can be re-used from this work for a future work? scientific? 2) Since you offer an application, I think a link to (com)test this application is essential. 3) In my opinion, the website http://terra.cl is close to what is proposed by this work. This is so, because terra allows users to register (profiles), comment on news, rate news, and configure the website to display the news that a user wants. 4) This could be a minor detail, I think that the use of social ne2rks could be used for something more than just showing the most important news (eg showing a kind of tracking (social) of a similar news(ies) ). column11: The article presents an application in the business field oriented to retail trade in the commercial company "Caracol" in Cuba. The theme of the work is fundamentally oriented to present and comment on the InfoCom application and how it eventually works in the company. However, in terms of its theoretical and methodological discussion and the analysis of the results, this article presents multiple shortcomings that are detailed below: The introduction of the article in general highlights the relevance of the application built for the company in particular but does not detail the innovative of this proposal and why this information system is better in terms of development or what are the characteristics that distinguish it from what currently exists in the market. Nor does the author clearly establish the motivation that has led him to develop a new solution for the problem posed. A research objective as such of the article is not defined since it is mentioned that this will be to "expose a commercial information system adaptable to any retail business......" . In general, it is desired to present the built application and it is not specified what is expected from the article, the methodologies to be used and what is innovative in terms of development for the discipline of information systems. One of the main limitations of this article is the state of the art. The review of the literature is almost non-existent in relation to the theories that support the development of the application and the main authors on platform development issues of this nature are not mentioned. No theoretical framework is established in the article in terms of design or implementation of the application. Proposals are not discussed in those terms either, so it is possible to say that there are no theoretical references in terms of analysis, design and implementation. This difficulty means that the evaluation of what has been developed is only based on general opinions about what the concept of information systems is. The research methodology is another important shortcoming of this article. The article moves between the importance of the application to a description of what is possible to do with it without establishing clear and accepted development and implementation methodologies (either for the design of the tool or for the analysis of the results obtained from its use). ). This complicates the evaluation of the work since there are no research questions to answer, nor ways to evaluate if the author's expectations are met or if the results obtained will be valid. The author of the article should present and describe the research designs to be used to allow their validity to be evaluated. Most of the article is in the development item and it defines and details the characteristics of the company in which the study will be developed. It is not clearly specified which parts of the system are acquired commercially and which are developed internally and how the connection with other existing platforms is achieved. Nor are process or data models associated with this construction established. The authors limit themselves to explaining the functionalities of the tool and how it will be used in the company, but it is not possible to know how it was implemented and compare the results that stand out as relevant from the implementation. Although the tool may be very simple from a design and architecture point of view, a description that presents process models using ad-hoc tools and at least a description of the design stage would be expected. The results obtained are generally mentioned as something that was achieved and as percentages of improvements in management and it is not possible to draw valid conclusions about them. The conclusion of the article is weak in terms of the results obtained from the design and implementation of the application and, above all, the contribution of the study to the discipline of information systems. I consider that the article requires major changes and that work must be done on the definition of the objective, the methodology to be used for the analysis and design of the platform. Therefore I suggest in this opportunity its rejection for this conference

column11: This work is framed in the area of business architecture and proposes an interesting business rules automation model to improve the flexibility of information systems applied to financial entities. The proposed model is aimed at decoupling business logic from business rules. The problem addressed in the article is adequately supported by the difficulties mentioned in the field of software projects and in the financial world. The author could go a little deeper into the experiences of project development in other areas and the relevance of business rules in the development of efficient information systems in the company. The objective declared by the author is to propose a methodology that allows flexibility in the operation of information systems in financial entities, which is generally explained adequately. The literature review is relevant to the issues addressed and the theories and models considered are appropriate to the objective that has been set. The analyzes associated with the concept of business rules and system architecture are related to the topic. The author should specify how the relationship between process modeling and the design and characterization of business rules is established. It is mentioned that they use the decision point tables, but these are not mentioned in detail or visually. The author should better support the choice of “Pipes and Filter” as the architecture model of the system. It would also be important to highlight if there are similar works carried out in other areas (since the author does not mention it) The methodological aspect of the work focuses on describing the process through which the definition of the software architecture is reached to automate the rules of business and the tools that were used in its development. This methodological approach is appropriate and is clearly associated with a case study application. The important contribution in this aspect is the detailed description of the process from the lifting of the rules to the design and development of the proposed application architecture. The author should make a summary table in which this process is represented in summary form. It is clear that the results of this work have the desired validity, since it is based on the use of models and tools already validated in the field of rule-based business platform design. The contribution of the work is important since it systematizes a process that is widely used in the development of information systems that are flexible and adaptable to the changing environment. However, these contributions are not clearly reflected in the conclusions, which is why it is suggested that the authors improve the conclusions, including significant contributions in methodological terms and contributions to the discipline in which the article is framed. The formal aspects of the work are satisfactory for the congress. There are minor details in the grammar such as in the first paragraph of the introduction that the letter U is missing. It is suggested to accept the article with minor modifications

Throughout the article, the role of test automation within software testing and more generally in the assurance framework is exaggerated. A maturity model for software testing necessarily includes more than just automation. Automated cases will always co-exist with manual cases and human assessments. As discussed in the article, automation is too general a concept, it can encompass generation, execution, evaluation (for example: mutation, coverage criteria) and validation (oracle problem). Although the motivation is clearly stated in the introduction, references are needed to substantiate the claims made about the role of testing and the impact of automation on testing. To say that automation makes testing faster or cheaper is simplistic: it depends on the context. The costs of generating automatic test cases, the estimation on the future evaluation of the software and the expiration of the test cases, along with other factors, must be taken into account in the cost model to determine the convenience of automating a certain part of the test. the proof. The section dedicated to software testing makes general definitions and walks through the history of testing since the mainframes. For a research article, I suggest making more specific definitions related to the focus of the study (experimental studies on test techniques, automation, test costs, maturity models). It would be appropriate to put the development of the maturity model after presenting the related work. The process to obtain the proposal of a maturity model for testing is not described. The development of the model must be linked to other existing maturity models (for example the Testing Maturity Model), establish connections with the accepted testing literature or standards (for example ISO 29119) and in general with software process models. The search string used is not specified. Not all models found should be classified as 'maturity models'. Some of the included models are clearly more general models, not addressing the problem of test automation. These differences should at least be discussed. The attributes used in table III are not explained, nor how to obtain the maturity level results. What does 'level of published reviews' mean? This concept is ambiguous. The description of this research process should be reinforced as it is key to obtaining the 'adolescent' level result.

column11: The paper is titled "Current Maturity of Software Test Automation Development." The document shows a series of sections that account for a work carried out in terms of literature review and some approaches to a proposal to restructure a particular scale of maturity levels for the test automation process. However, the work lacks a logical structure that allows determining if its contribution or main objective is in the literature review or in the proposal of new levels of maturity for the testing process. It is recommended to make a complete review of the information presented and possibly restructure the document presented. The report of this review was divided into sections, in order to provide suggestions to improve the work. Section -Systematic Review It is important that the authors review the fact of using a systematic review method that has not yet been published, since there are several published, tested and recognized methods for Software engineering. They should justify the selection of the method proposed by Serna M. identified with the number [16] in the work. It is essential to explain the validation that is done regarding the peer review of the articles, since it is not clear how a peer review of the published articles can be accessed in order to validate them and how a validation process is carried out from of said information, taking into account the number of revisions that would have to be made for each article found (978). Test automation Although, in the work a proposed model is reported to evaluate the maturity of the software test automation process. The model as such is not described. The article is limited to presenting a reference scale associated with the maturity of a human being. Therefore, it is essential that the article indicates several aspects to consider the structuring and definition of a model. Among the most important aspects to consider are: 1. A scientific and formal justification on which the authors of the work are based to propose the maturity model and the selection of the maturity levels of a human being as a point of comparison with a possible maturity level of the test automation process. 2. Formal justification of why not to use the CMMI model and the structure of maturity levels proposed in it to evaluate the test automation process. The foregoing, taking into account that the maturity model defines an appropriate maturity scale to evaluate processes in software engineering. In other words, why is it necessary to rethink those maturity levels for the test automation process and propose a new scale based on the maturity of a human being? 3. At the research level, how are maturity levels characterized in terms of test automation? Although the article characterizes each level indicating the possible characteristics in which the test automation process is, it does not indicate how said characterization was determined, nor is a related formal and scientific justification shown. Related work The work presents a systematic review, under which it is possible to identify work related to the area of study, in this case test automation or maturity levels for test automation. However, the authors present the systematic review separately from the related work section, when it appears that the studies selected as related work should be part of the analysis of the results of the systematic review. In addition, the systematic review allows the identification of research gaps or niches (research opportunities) to determine a work area with a specific problem and, from there, propose a possible solution to said problem. In this case, the article presents the systematic review as an additional work and subsequent to the proposal of maturity levels for the test automation process. Likewise, the authors show the selection of some related works, it is understood that they are related to test automation, notwithstanding the first Michael Grottke, they indicate precisely that it does not focus on the subject to be treated in the work they present but on a Statistical proposal of test automation. Therefore it would not enter as related work. Software Test Automation Development Maturity To compare the test automation process and its maturity levels, the authors present Table 3. It indicates that the first column lists the traditional stages of a test automation process. testing process. It is necessary to indicate under what methodology these stages are selected as traditional or to have a reference as justification for the selection of these and not other stages. In this section there is no clear explanation of the determination of maturity levels at each stage. It is essential to have a description of the research analysis carried out, which results in the definition of the maturity level of each of the stages of the testing process. The table is not a sufficient explanation for the analysis, since it only reports the results. At this point, if what is sought is to propose a new maturity scale for the test process or test automation, the most convenient thing is to validate said proposed scale with a case study. In this work, although the authors show a table where they seem to determine that the maturity level is "adolescent", it is not possible to understand in what context the test automation process is being evaluated. At least one case should be contextualized where it is indicated: region, time, type of projects or companies and methodology used to evaluate the test automation process. The foregoing is the basis for justifying that in a given context the test automation process is at X level of maturity (of the proposed scale). Arguing, in addition, the criteria that were taken into account to assign said level of maturity.

Other minor comments: - The translation of the abstract into English should be reviewed. - The bibliography of software quality, comes from textbooks, and can be updated. - The scope towards quality taxes is, at the same time, introduced as part of the methodological framework, and exposed as conclusions. The article reviews quality definitions, software quality and quality models. Some models are treated first in a preliminary section and others after the theoretical analysis, I suggest re-organizing the presentation of concepts. In my opinion, the concepts of quality model and conceptual model are not equivalent, although they are treated together in the introduction. In the second section several models are presented, but the relationships between them and what is the criterion to take them into account in this line of research is not clearly established. There are multiple proposals for software quality models and specific models for the web. On the other hand, the OWASP guides are relevant to web application security, not a model of quality. I suggest exposing the theoretical analysis (which includes basic definitions of quality) before the description and justification of the models considered. On the other hand, specific quality concepts/attributes/models could be added in the context of banking systems. In my opinion, devoting so much space to defining the concept of electronic banking, internet banking and then mobile banking is not necessary in the current state of the art and public knowledge of these concepts. I suggest focusing on the research objectives of this particular work. The descriptions of the DESMET methodological framework and the research-action methodology are very brief. It is necessary to establish the objectives of the research beforehand. The conceptual models obtained are the main result of the work. More readable notations should be used (I also suggest putting extended information as an annex to the article or on the web). It should also be explained how these models were validated, so that they are reliable if they are used to define ontologies or used in later works.

The article reflects on the current state and possible projections of formal methods in software development. There are many assertions made in the document that do not have bibliographic citations to support them, nor do they follow from a logical deduction from from previous premises. This significantly detracts from the validity of the arguments presented. 2. All the assertions presented in the document that, according to the interpretation, the authors want to present as their own, are, in fact, widely known problems in the area of formal methods. In summary, the article does not provide assertions with sufficient evidence or a solid line of argument, nor does it provide original assertions. For these reasons, I consider that the article is not suitable for publication.

column11: The open data of Chile This work analyzes in a general way an issue that has acquired real relevance in governments worldwide, open data. The problem addressed by the article is adequately supported by the existing needs to provide data to assess transparency and public interest. An applied research is carried out on the main government web platforms in Chile. The objective is declared by the author and establishes that the state of open data in Chile is presented and a diagnosis is made of the main sites and tools provided by the state to improve transparency and enhance citizen participation. The literature review is relevant to the topic but quite general. The model used to measure the quality of data on the web is chosen without justification through an analysis that establishes its efficiency compared to other models. The review that is carried out of the concept of open data is minimal and is not present in the review carried out as this issue has been addressed in different countries and the results they have obtained. The authors should further delve into the concept of open data at the government level for transparency and the public interest and better support this division in the literature. The methodological aspect of the work focuses on using the 5-star model and describing a general classification based on this model. Although this methodological approach is adequate and is clearly associated with the subject, it does not present propositions to be evaluated (research questions or hypotheses to be tested). The diagnosis is basic and general based on four variables that allow each platform to be classified. The author should also establish a categorization of what the study subjects are (the government of Chile is mentioned but there are only four platforms out of the total number of platforms owned by the government). In this sense, it should refer to transversal central service platforms (since it does not analyze local governments at any time). This work is based on the use of a diagnostic model already validated in the literature, however its application is limited and, in my opinion, it does not allow generalize to the government as a whole. The contribution of the work is important since it presents relevant information in the process of reaching what is open government. However, the generalizability of their results is questionable as it is limited to four variables and four websites. The main contributions of the article are not clearly reflected in the conclusions and it is suggested that the authors improve them by including aspects relevant to the subject evaluated (the websites), the contributions to the study of open government in Chile and to recognize the limitations that this study has. study. The formal aspects of the work are satisfactory for the congress.

The authors follow the SEMMA and CRISP-DM methodologies for the development of the project. Throughout the paper, the authors describe the methodology phase, the work carried out, and the results obtained in that phase, except in the data mining (and clustering) phase, where the authors postpone the description of the work and the results. to section 5 of the paper. This makes the structure of the paper not entirely clear. Another thing is the simplification of the variables to be taken into account when carrying out the data mining process, since other aspects related to the client, the receiver, ... would have to be taken into account.

The article deals with a data mining process aimed at describing groups for the analysis of money laundering in the banking sector. It uses the CRISP-DM process as a methodological reference and follows it with some dedication. As for the substance: it details too many aspects that are related to the descriptive part of the financial topic and the bank in particular where the development of the work is circumscribed. It also emphasizes obtaining the mineable view, which is fine, but neglects the generation of the data mining model, specifically it does not show the clustering model, nor the levels of coverage and confidence in each rule of each cluster, it does not perform a statistical analysis about patterns and there is no validation of the model and patterns obtained. The latter is the greatest weakness of the work. In reference to the form: there are many spelling and writing errors, excessive length of some paragraphs and writing of some topics that should be summarized, it also writes in the fourth person and in some parts in the future tense, it should standardize the writing in the 3rd person and present tense, except in the conclusions that can occupy past tense. exceeds no. of pages set maximum. Finally, it presents little bibliography (only 4) and also no references anywhere. It is an article that can be accepted but requires a profound rearrangement in terms of form, and fundamentally in relation to the data mining model, its analysis and exhaustive evaluation, as well as its results.

In this work, a systematic review of the literature on the subject of software requirements management in small companies is carried out. The work is relevant for the community given the little existing information on this subject. As minor corrections, it is recommended to work more on the results section, adding the summary of the review as well as discussing the results according to the research question posed. Lastly, it is recommended to remove the reference that appears in the abstract.

Regarding the general aspects, three things: 1) the authors should be consistent with the nomenclature used: mainly requirements vs. requirements: please, use only one of the 2 denominations, but do not mix at will. 2) Second, small settings (small environments) vs small and medium enterprises. If you go to the definition given by the SEI, you will see that it is not the same, the concept of small setting being broader. In this case I think the authors are referring to small businesses. 3) As a third comment, general, check the punctuation marks, very long sentences. In the summary, the authors indicate that they are going to offer a work proposal for small environments. I can't find that job proposal in the article. Also, it is better not to put references in the abstract. In the introduction, second paragraph, it appears "since this allows to guarantee FROM ..." an UNTIL SUCH THING is expected... In the systematic review process section, it is not necessary to make a subsection, it does not make much sense to divide a thing in one section. In the systematic review phases grant, they first say there are 3 steps and then they call it phases. Which of the 2 is it??? The names given to the phases do not coincide with those of the following sections, nor with those of Figure 1. Figure 1 does not contribute anything. In the planning section, words like "over" are not very valid in written language. Likewise, in the planning they include paragraphs that justify the reason for the SMEs, this is already out of context here. They also indicate that the objective of the review is to find models, methodologies, proposals or processes related to requirements management. Well, this is what they are expected to obtain in the results of the systematic review, and this hardly appears (it only appears a list of methodologies and little else). They also mix improvement of software processes with improvement of requirements management. Then they indicate that the results are measured by the number of proposals... when previously they have said otherwise. The sections of the review do not faithfully follow those of Kitchenham, and Biolchini. Likewise, in the "search string" part, "is that" appears, which in written language does not look good. The list of sources, why does it appear in the search string grant? In the revision part, Table 3 and Figure 2 are redundant, if one more column is added to the table, indicating the corresponding percentage, we have the same effect. In the Review part, YOU CANNOT DECIDE TO INCLUDE ONLY THE FIRST 20, so why do we do the systematic review???? Also a single grant???. What are the 20 items you selected? Where are they referenced? The same happens with Figure 4 and Table 4. Regarding the Results, it is to be assumed that references 18 to 29 are the primary articles??? In these results they only indicate justifications related to requirements management, but nothing related to what they indicate in the objective of their systematic review. Based on a reference from 2007, number 24, they indicate that it had not dealt with the management of requirements in small companies. I only indicate a doctoral thesis from the UPM of November 2013, entitled Metamodel for the improvement of the requirements management process, whose author is Ariel E. Serrano Rico and Director Jose A. Calvo-Manzano, so that you can see that there are things on requirements management. This is also the only site where they indicate a series of methodologies. This, which is supposed to be one of the expected results, only appears in 2 lines of the results section. Then it adds a series of key factors, and conditions that seem to appear by themselves, without any reference and that are also not the objective that the authors say regarding the review they have made.
